t: Job 14
Job Speaks of the Finality of Death
“Man,*pn who is born of woman, Is*ln short-lived and full of turmoil.
Like*ln a flower he comes forth and withers. He*ln also flees like a shadow and does not remain.
You*ln also open Your eyes on him And*ln bring him into judgment with Yourself.
Who*ln can make the clean out of the unclean? No*ln one!
Since*ln his days are determined, The*ln number of his months is with You; And*ln his limits You have set so that he cannot pass.
Turn*ln Your gaze from him that he may rest, Until*ln he fulfills his day like a hired man.
“For*ln there is hope for a tree, When*ln it is cut down, that it will sprout again, And*ln its shoots will not fail.
Though*ln its roots grow old in the ground And*ln its stump dies in the dry soil,
At*ln the scent of water it will flourish And*ln put forth sprigs like a plant.
But*ln man dies and lies prostrate. Man*ln expires, and where is he?
As*iln water evaporates from the sea, And*ln a river becomes parched and dried up,
So*ln man lies down and does not rise. Until*ln the heavens are no longer, He*ln will not awake nor be aroused out of his sleep.
“Oh*ln that You would hide me in Sheol, That*ln You would conceal me until Your wrath returns to*i You,*i That*ln You would set a limit for me and remember me!
If*ln a man dies, will he live again?*i All*ln the days of my struggle I will wait Until*ln my change comes.
You*ln will call, and I will answer You; You*ln will long for the work of Your hands.
For*ln now You number my steps, You*ln do not observe my sin.
My*ln transgression is sealed up in a bag, And*ln You wrap up my iniquity.
“But*ln the falling mountain crumbles away, And*ln the rock moves from its place;
Water*ln wears away stones, Its*ln torrents wash away the dust of the earth; So*ln You destroy man’s hope.
You*ln forever overpower him and he departs; You*iln change his appearance and send him away.
His*ln sons achieve honor, but he does not know it;*i Or*ln they become insignificant, but he does not perceive it.
But*ln his body pains him, And*ln he mourns only for himself.”
